title.narrative: Project On Applied Research On Health Aspects Of Low Income Settlements

description.narrative: Health questionnaires are increasingly based on telecommunication. The respondent records answers to a short questionnaire on a mobile phone. This method has two immediate advantages; it is inexpensive in comparison to data collection by a third party and it enables outcomes to be collected from disparate and mobile populations. It may have a third advantage in terms of data quality in some circumstances as we shall discuss.Diarrhoea is one of the two largest causes of death in children under the age of five. Major water and sewage interventions are underway and planned to deal with this problem in LMICs. However, collecting relevant data on diarrhoea prevalence on a suffcient scale to monitor the effects of interventions has proven difficult. The standard questions used, for example in the ubiquitous Demographic Health Surveys, enquires about childhood diarrhoea over the past three or five days. Since memory over this time is fallible and since the presence or absence of diarrhoea is not totally objective, this method of data collection is likely to be non-specific (i.e. yields false positives). We hypothesise that a question covering the most immediate past period (last 24 hours), would improve the accuracy of data collection. This would be combined with other measures, such as re-wording the questionnaire to elicit more severe (less ambiguous) cases.
